## In sum {data-menu-title="In sum, most Republicans..."}

::: {.column width="50%"}
Most Republicans [support](https://climatecommunication.yale.edu/publications/climate-change-in-the-american-mind-politics-policy-spring-2025/toc/5/): 

- Schools teaching about global warming
- US participation in Paris Agreement
- Funding research for wind and solar
- Regulating CO2
- Tax credits for electrification 
- Using more renewables, less fossil fuels
- Solar and wind on public lands

Most Republicans [oppose](https://climatecommunication.yale.edu/publications/climate-change-in-the-american-mind-politics-policy-spring-2025/toc/5/): 

- Blocking offshore wind farms
- Ordering agencies to stop researching global warming 
- Ordering agencies to stop providing info on global warming to the public 
- Eliminating FEMA
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}

Most people in Texas, Arizona, New Mexico, Florida, Nevada, North Carolina, South Carolina, Georgia (and most other states) believe that climate change is [already causing](https://climatecommunication.yale.edu/publications/attribution-across-america/)

- Extreme heat
- Wildfires
- Flooding
- Hurricanes 
- Drought AND 
- Rising sea levels

(only in WV and ND do majorities **not** think climate change is already having an impact)
:::

## Week 8: Ecofeminist Critique

> Care work is low-emissions, improving lives without material production and consumption --> reproducitve labor pink collar jobs are green. Ecosystems do uncompensated reproductive work too. 

> "Capitalism depends on the socially reproductive labor of the household, and by calling that work an act of love, makes it free...As with Wages for Housework, in which the concrete demand for payment acted as a provocative starting point, the demand for payment for work done to and by ecosystems was originally meant as an unsettling metaphor." (Battistoni, *Alive in the Sunshine*)

- What is the ecofeminist critique? Specifically, what is the argument about reproductive work? What are the implications of this argument for climate policy?
